Mr. Speaker, the CJSS-CFLG radio station strike in Cornwall, Ontario has been in progress for nearly seven months. The strike has caused considerable hardship for the station and its employees, and it is in no one's interest for it to continue any longer.
June 9, 1992

In any strike, conciliation and compromise are required from both sides if a resolution is to be obtained. I call upon the Minister of Labour and officials in his department to use every means at their disposal in order to bring management and labour together to begin constructive negotiations aimed at obtaining an acceptable and equitable conclusion to this labour dispute.
It is clear that the employer and employees of radio station CJSS-CFLG need outside assistance if they are to end this debilitating strike.
It is my hope that Labour Canada can bring the two parties together and help them reach a mutual acceptable agreement that will put an end to this damaging strike which has gone on far too long.

subtopic: TRIBUTE TO FEDORA AND FLORENT FORTIN
TRIBUTE TO FEDORA AND FLORENT FORTIN
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to pay tribute today to my constituents Fedora and Florent Fortin and their 13 children, who were just honoured at the 93rd provincial convention of the Knights of Columbus as family of the year in Quebec.
The reputation of Florent Fortin and his wife Fedora goes far beyond their native village of Launay. In Taschereau, Amos or Val d'Or, from Temiscamingue to the northern tip of Abitibi, many remember spending a happy evening at the home of Florent and Fedora, this couple whose hospitality is legendary.
In my region of Abitibi, no association, initiative, community undertaking or celebration has not benefited from the enthusiastic contribution of the Fortin family.
Mr. Speaker, congratulations to Fedora and Florent Fortin for their dedication to community service and their exemplary success in family life.

Mr. Speaker, the federal cabinet is to spend $4.3 billion on helicopters
to combat a Soviet threat that no longer exists. The government also plans to spend $100 million for a referendum whose answer will not be binding. The same government is spending millions on a PR campaign that says Canadians can do it.
One thing the government has not been able to do is to deal with the disgraceful shortfall in housing aboriginal people.
A 20,000 unit backlog is responsible for social problems which take an enormous toll on aboriginal families who often live 20 at a time in houses without indoor plumbing or clean water.
For example, $1 million was recently spent in Arviat on Hudson Bay to treat the health effects of an epidemic related to poor sanitation. One million dollars spent on housing in that community could have eliminated that problem.
Canadians are asking: "If Canada can do it, why can this government not get its priorities straight?"

Mr. Speaker, this is Safe Boating Week in Canada.
This campaign by the Coast Guard and the Safe Boating Council is an attempt to emphasize the importance of boating education, the prevention of drinking and boating, and over-all safety on the water. I commend this effort.
However more needs to be done. Boats on the market today travel at ever increasing speeds. All one has to do is head down to the local waterfront and witness the tremendous danger that can be involved in pleasure boating.
Over 50 per cent of search and rescue efforts by the Coast Guard are in response to pleasure craft accidents. Yet, unlike automobiles, a person does not have to be licensed in any way to operate one of these craft. Anyone from the age of one to 100 is permitted to drive a pleasure boat regardless of experience or ability.
I call on the Coast Guard during Safe Boating Week to establish new regulations governing pleasure boating that include mandatory licensing for all operators.

June 9, 1992

Mr. Speaker, the National Action Committee on the Status of Women has called for a complete restructuring of the blue ribbon panel on violence against women. This is neither practicable nor possible at this late date.
It may well be that the membership of the panel was not as representative of the diversity of Canadian women as it should have been. However the members of the panel themselves are tried and true workers in the battle against violence. To blame them for the shortfalls in the terms of reference goes against principles of fairness and seriously jeopardizes the good work that has been done.
NAC makes the mistake, as does the government, of thinking that the panel is the only vehicle in the fight against violence. We in the Liberal Party want to see its reports before we make a judgment. We also want to remind all of those engaged in the battle against violence that we must stand together and that we must continue to press for mandatory training of judges, appropriate police protocols and emergency courts for women in crisis. We do not serve ourselves or Canadian women in general by fractionalizing our own movement.
The panel has made some mistakes. Surely we are all human. I call on national women's groups and all women to stand together in this battle. Let us not throw out the baby with the bath water.

Mr. Speaker, among the many valuable job training initiatives which the Government of Canada has been taking in recent years, few would appear to be more uniquely successful than the Jobstart Program which has been conducted by a volunteer community organization in Oromocto, New Brunswick.
Over the past several years the continuing track record has been maintained of all young citizens who have completed Jobstart training. The results indicate that employment stability of more than 70 per cent has been maintained by Jobstart graduates during that time.
The special features of the Jobstart concept are those that teach the work ethic in a full-fledged employment
scenario. The participants are not called students but rather employees and they learn the disciplines of holding a job on a first-hand basis. In addition, of course, they receive general training in the fundamental skills and habits necessary to survive in the work force.
The innovative training program is also very cost effective for society because it has a high record of helping people break out of the welfare trap.
The Jobstart Program deserves a continuing place in the training structure of the Canada employment system.

Mr. Speaker, on June 4 of this year the right hon. Prime Minister received a letter from the premier of the province of British Columbia, the hon. Michael Har-court. I will quote three paragraphs from this letter. It starts by saying:
After much consideration, the Government of British Columbia has determined that Canadian interests would be best served by Canada withdrawing from the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) negotiations and not signing a NAFTA.
It is clear from the actions of the Government of the United States over the past few weeks that it is not willing to live by the spirit of the commitments made in the Canada-U.S. Free Hade Agreement (FTA). These actions include the recent softwood lumber dispute and the Honda case, both of which are clearly politically motivated trade disputes that violate the commitment to fair trade between the two countries.
Therefore, I believe strongly that it is premature to consider entering another preferential trade agreement with the United States given the problems associated with the FTA.
I want to congratulate the premier of the province of British Columbia for taking this position. I want to say to the federal government that it should either pay attention to this letter or suffer the peril in the province of British Columbia.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Canada Post first tested supermailboxes in my riding of Fraser Valley East. Through a good communications campaign and a willingness to consult, supermailboxes were a success.

Now, to the surprise of many, in the municipality of Matsqui in my riding Canada Post seems to have forgotten its own secret to success. In a veiy high-handed way Canada Post has decided to locate supermailboxes in the middle of people's lawns. I am not kidding.
A simple notice to say it is coming was issued. No consultation took place; no recourse was available. The next thing we know, trees were ripped out, holes were dug, a water main broken, Canada Post's reputation was shot, and 300 people were signing a petition.
Things are moving fast here, but what we really need is some common sense and some understanding. Residents and Canada Post alike want to get rid of the old green boxes and want some improved service.
I encourage Canada Post to stop its high-handed and arbitrary actions in the McMillan Heights area of Matsqui and meet with the residents affected to reach an amiable agreement suitable to all parties involved.
I have now been assured by Canada Post that it will meet with the people affected.

Mr. Speaker, for quite some time the government has been telling Canadians they have to be well trained to compete globally. However it seems the Tories are unwilling to take their own advice.
Thousands of Canadians across the country are looking for training assistance. The government says it has poured millions of dollars into the UI fund to help provide training. Sadly for those many Canadians whose UI has run out they are ineligible for help.
For our young people in universities learning the skills of tomorrow, the Conservatives have cut funding for post-secondary education. The resulting higher tuition has forced many youth to give up on a university education.
The government should listen to its own advice and help Canadians get the job training they need to enter the 21st century.

Mr. Speaker, I rise today to speak on a subject that is very dear to us in this Chamber, perhaps too dear. I am referring to the pensions that you and I will receive as members of Parliament. I believe there must be some changes to the pension rules.
First, no one should be eligible to receive a pension until they are at least 55 or 60 years of age. Second, no one should be permitted to draw an MPs pension and also receive a salary from a government job. Third, I believe MPs should be eligible after four years of service but should not start drawing the pension until they reach retirement age.
My constituents want to know where we stand on this issue. This is where I stand and have stood there since I was elected. I ask all members to consider what I have said very carefully.

Mr. Speaker, the Elliot Lake Retirement Living Caravan is stationed on Parliament Hill. It is located near the west members' entrance.
The caravan is a travelling information display which tells all about Elliot Lake retirement living, a non-profit housing program offering rent to seniors from just $285 per month. Since its inception in 1987 the program has attracted over 2,000 seniors to this beautiful city on the north shore of Lake Huron.
More than 1,100 housing units in Elliot Lake are now occupied by seniors in the retirement living program and there are some 400 more units available for rent this year.
Over 2,000 senior citizens from many parts of Canada have discovered the enjoyment and economic freedom of living in this friendly city of 13,000 with excellent community facilities and low housing costs.
The caravan is funded through a grant from the FEDNOR program. I invite all, including all MPs and senators, to visit the Elliot Lake Retirement Living Caravan today on Parliament Hill to learn what an excellent opportunity this is for affordable housing for our senior citizens.

Mr. Speaker, I strongly believe that our government should Canadianize and restore the Victoria Cross medal as the highest accolade for an act of valour in the face of the enemy.
In 1972 when the previous government brought in the new Canadian orders of bravery the Victoria Cross was omitted. I believe it is time this policy was reversed. The Victoria Cross should be reinstated and awarded by the Governor General on the advice of the government of the day.
After listening to the many views of many veterans on this issue, I strongly believe the Victoria Cross should once again resume its position as a distinguished part of Canada's awards for gallantry.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday, in response to my leader, the Minister of National Health and Welfare implied that provincial New Democrat governments were no better than his when it comes to child care. This is unfair, insulting, and shows the minister's inadequate knowledge of child care in Canada.
In my home province of British Columbia the New Democrat government chose to add $17 million for child care support programs including additional funds for infant and toddler care.
In Saskatchewan, a province reeling from debt left by the previous Tory government, the New Democrats chose to create a child care advisory board and chose to allocate over $14 million for child care.
In Ontario the New Democrat government chose to create a child care task force and $75 million has been targeted over five years. Knowing it is essential for individuals seeking training to have access to child care, Jobs Ontario includes the creation of 20,000 new spaces.
The New Democrat government in Yukon also chose to bring in child care reform.
What have the Tories done? They chose to cap the Canada Assistance Plan for B.C., Ontario, and Alberta, and have limited the funds to child care.

Mr. Speaker, recently I asked my constituents for their advice and suggestions. I would like to share some of the responses with the House.
Dave Cannon of Caledon East has this advice: Keep interest rates below 10 per cent; keep inflation low; reduce taxes, especially the GST) fund public works projects; reduce unemployment; and increase funding for education and retraining.
O. Schewchun of Campbellville writes: The Canadian future I believe will improve when we elect people who truly represent the majority view of constituents and do not blindly follow and support their political party line. Politicians must remember they are elected to represent, not elected to lead.
Elaine Lawlor of Palgrave writes: We want to stay proud Canadians. We want the tops in education and medical research. We want to work for our future. We want our children to know how to work rather than to be handed too much. We want safety in our cities. We want our children to be able to play in the parks again. We want alcohol advertising prohibited and we want French in Quebec and English in the rest of Canada.
Thank you, Mr. Speaker, for allowing the voices of my constituents to be heard in Parliament.

Mr. Speaker, the government wants to keep the Canadian family as the basis of this country, but is demolishing everything that could help it get out of hard times. This Conservative government denies that many families are headed and financially supported by single women. One parent families are a reality in 1992.

Eliminating tax breaks for common law couples, killing a national day care program, introducing a targeted system of child benefits are not what is needed to help
June 9, 1992

those who care but struggle to keep their families as an entity.

This government is doing nothing to help create a future for the thousands of children who survive thanks to food banks. It believes only in the traditional type of family and forgets about the others.
If we want a strong nation, it is high time to stop living in the past and to face today's reality of the very large number of broken families that are asking for the help promised by this government. This situation must change.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask the Prime Minister a question. Speaking to mayors from all over Canada on Sunday in Montreal, the Minister of Transport told them that the government could not participate in a program to rebuild the cities' infrastructure and create jobs immediately, because it did not have money. Today, we learn that the government is preparing to spend $4.3 billion to buy 50 helicopters for the Canadian forces. These helicopters will not even be made in Canada; they will be made in Europe.
I therefore ask the Prime Minister why the government is considering spending $4.3 billion to buy military equipment when the government does not have a single dollar to help unemployed Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, I think that the Leader of the Opposition is mistaken. The government must make decisions on Canada's national security and national defence on the basis of recommendations from the military authorities. We shall see if it is necessary to buy this particular equipment. If so, the Minister of National Defence will report to the House of Commons in due course.
As for the statement made by the Minister of Transport in Montreal, he stated the obvious fact that we do
Oral Questions
not have $14 or $15 billion to spend on municipal infrastructure. As the hon. member for Halifax said yesterday, you in the Liberal Party do not have the money to finance a national child care program. That is realistic. Our position is rather like that. We cannot spend money we do not have. But in his budget, the Minister of Finance spoke of government involvement in road infrastructure, and we are looking into it with the provinces. I have the impression that within a few days or weeks, there will be an important statement about it.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Prime Minister does not want to create a bad impression.

But it is not a program of $15 billion by the federal government. It is a program of $1 billion per year for five years. The provincial government will pay one-third, the municipalities will pay one-third and there will be jobs created right away.
Coming back to this question of buying 50 helicopters for $4.3 billion at this time, this program has been under discussion for 10 years. The government should know that the world has changed a lot in the last 10 years. I would like to know if the Prime Minister would reconsider this decision and make sure that other priorities come first, like the creation of jobs and having money for programs and the training of the unemployed so they will be ready when prosperity returns to Canada.

speakeroldname: Hon. Marcel Masse (Minister of National Defence):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to inform the Leader of the Opposition that the only decision which has been made in this regard was made by his government about fifteen years ago, and that was to replace our frigates.
Now, those frigates will require helicopters, since those in use at present are nearly 30 years old and need to be replaced. The government has the matter under advisement. A decision will be made and the House will be apprised of it in due course, as the Prime Minister has said.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary for the Minister of Finance.

Oral Questions
As I said earlier, that decision may indeed have been under consideration for 10 years, but it is the normal result of a situation which, at the time, made new frigates necessary. But the world has changed completely during that time.
That is why I would like the Minister of National Defence to tell me whether those billions of dollars might not be better spent meeting urgent societal needs now that the cold war is over.

speakeroldname: Hon. Marcel Masse (Minister of National Defence):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, if I am to take the Leader of the Opposition literally, we should cancel the frigate building program now, including those under construction in New Brunswick and Quebec. I do not think that the government, in its wisdom, will make such a decision.
Second, as far as on-board helicopters are concerned, we are aware, just like the Leader of the Opposition, that the world has changed. That matter will be among those raised by my cabinet colleagues, as the minister does himself in his department, and in due course a decision will be made and the population will be informed.

Mr. Speaker, I would point out that there is a big difference between the frigate program approved by the Liberals and this program. The frigates are made in Canada and these helicopters will not be.
I understand that in fact the jobs created by the Sea King replacement program will be 3,000. I understand that the same amount of money spent on public transportation would create 40 times as many jobs and if spent on education, would probably create 75 times as many jobs.
Can the minister stand on his feet and tell this House and the Canadian public that, given the state of the world, the Canadian economy, the state of our infrastructure, education and public transportation, that the government's priority is right at this time?

speakeroldname: Hon. Marcel Masse (Minister of National Defence):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would remind the honourable member that it was decided 125 years ago that one of the reasons
there should be a Canadian confederation was to defend our territory together.
That in my view is one of our basic responsibilities under confederation. The government equips our Armed Forces in accordance with recommendations made by professionals in that field, and this is what the government is going to do.
The honourable member may rest assured that the government will not make any decisions without consulting the experts nor without having asked all the essential questions, including details regarding this important project.

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate what the minister had to say. It did not really address the question that I asked though. If I could ask a supplementary. This works out to $1.4 million a job. That is a pretty expensive job creation program, if you look at it that way.
I want to remind the House and this government that there is a likelihood of tens of thousands of Atlantic Canadians being out of work if the northern cod catch program is going to be shut down, as the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans suggested it might have to be.
The government is looking at $45 million for those who may be unemployed because of this, $45 million for over 30,000 Canadians. That is going to be very hard to explain in Atlantic Canada. Can the minister tell this House that the government can truly afford the Sea King replacement program and at the same time afford adequate compensation for those Canadians who will be unemployed in the not too distant future in the fishing industry?

speakeroldname: Hon. Marcel Masse (Minister of National Defence):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would remind the honourable member that Canada allocates 1.8 or 1.9 per cent of its gross domestic product to defence, whereas other western countries earmark 4 per cent for this purpose, or even 6 per cent in the case of the United States. To what extent can we avoid providing for the defence of our territory and still remain an independent country?
June 9, 1992

Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, on the question of the submarines, the threats these helicopters are designed to meet according to all reports is a threat that has collapsed, in case the government has not noticed. It has collapsed along with the Berlin wall. It has collapsed along with the Soviet Union. It has collapsed along with the Warsaw Pact. In fact, the government is inviting Boris Yeltsin to lunch over at the Museum of Civilization next week.
Will not the government concede that the Hunt for Red October was last year's movie?

Mr. Speaker, I was impressed with the enumeration of various threats that had disappeared by the NDP. They ticked off a threat that had gone here and a threat that had gone there and a threat that had gone somewhere else. It was very impressive. Yet, when a real threat emerged in Iraq, the NDP did not see it.
When it came time to take a position on a real and genuine threat that existed, the NDP did not see that threat. As the minister of defence is pointing out, Canada cannot afford the kind of imprudence suggested by the NDP. We must be ready to meet legitimate threats when they occur, threats that affect the national interest of Canada or alternatively threats that affect our obligations as members of the United Nations.
When the United Nations called and asked for democracies to respond to the challenge, the NDP said no. The Liberals said: "At the first sign of gun-fire, we are calling the troops home". Well, that is not what Canada wants.

Mr. Speaker, the Prime Minister is an expert, not only on Red October but red herrings, because on the whole issue of Iraq, of course, he has missed the point.
The issue here is, first of all, the Prime Minister is saying this is a necessary purchase and then minutes later the Minister of National Defence is saying they are going to consult experts and make a decision. I think it is important for the government to be absolutely frank with the Canadian people here. Has a decision been made to proceed with this atrocious and ludicrous expenditure of public funds or has it not?

speakeroldname: Hon. Marcel Masse (Minister of National Defence):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the government has not yet arrived at a decision in this regard. The Minister of National Defence has not reported to his colleagues, nor has he submitted any proposal concerning the acquisition of helicopters. A proposal will be made by the minister in due time and cabinet will take it under advisement and make a decision. This is not the exact opposite of what the Prime Minister has said. The government has a national defence policy and we implement it.

Mr. Speaker, I would hope that before the government makes a decision it can agree that there should be a full public discussion with the experts involved coming before a committee of this House. It finally boils down to a question of priorities.

How can the minister explain to hungiy children in Montreal why he has decided to spend $91 million for a single helicopter and $4 billion dollars for the entire project?

How can he explain it to a battered woman seeking help in Victoria or families out of work all across Canada? Is it not the time for all parties in this House to come together to achieve a real peace dividend for Canadians as other countries are doing all around the world?

speakeroldname: Hon. Marcel Masse (Minister of National Defence):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, if we consider the professionalism of our troops and their dedication, Canada's peace dividend for the past 20 years has been the highest of any country in the world.
The percentage of Gross National Product spent on national defence in this country was the lowest of any country in the world.
In any event, the peace dividend has been paid for the past 20 years, and you are already cashing in on the interest.

June 9, 1992
Oral Questions

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is to the Prime Minister.
Twenty-six men have lost their lives at the bottom of the Westray coal mine. Taxpayers are going to lose millions of dollars and certain other persons will benefit handsomely as a result. Now the Government of Nova Scotia is about to flaunt the Westray coal mine.
Will the Prime Minister indicate to the House as to whether or not he is prepared to have a parliamentary inquiry into this particular matter and if not, why not?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am in receipt of the letter from the House leader of the Liberal Party in respect of that. I am sure he is aware that the main issue of safety is the provincial responsibility of Nova Scotia and there is a judicial inquiry going on. I am sure he would not want us to prejudice that inquiry.
The member recognizes, as he acknowledged in his letter, that the government has been forthcoming with all of the background documents necessary for people to examine what has occurred and reach their own conclusions. I am also sure he would recognize that having another separate so-called study would not really serve any useful purpose at this time.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my supplementary is to the minister who responded.
The minister knows and I know that what I am suggesting will not interfere one iota with the judicial inquiry in the province of Nova Scotia. In fact it would buttress and facilitate that process.
Week after week we have heard from the minister of state for small business who sounds like a broken record: "Don't ask me. Ask the people of Nova Scotia." He is right. There are certain answers the provincial government can give, but there are also certain answers that ministers of the federal Crown ought to give.
I ask the Prime Minister again. Is the Prime Minister not prepared now to proceed with a parliamentary
inquiry to get to the bottom of a national disaster which has caused the loss of 26 lives in this country?

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, everyone in this House was very concerned and hurt when news of this disaster occurred.
There was an accident. We do not know at this point in time whether there was laxity in terms of safety precautions or whether in fact the regulations were appropriate or inappropriate. These are the fundamental questions that are being examined by the judicial inquiry in Nova Scotia which will ascertain and undoubtedly produce recommendations that will reduce the possibility of that kind of thing happening again.
If the member has concern about establishing the facts behind how this accident occurred, I think he would agree that the judicial inquiry going on in Nova Scotia is the proper vehicle for making that determination. We ought to await that rather than try to interfere with it.

speakeroldname: Mr. Francis G. LeBlanc (Cape Breton Highlands - Canso):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
One month ago today, 26 miners lost their lives in the Westray disaster. One month later, we still have not received a straight answer from this government as to how it could have financed this unsafe project. What this government has done instead is to throw up road-blocks in the path of the truth. Enough is enough.
Will the Prime Minister not now agree to our call for a special parliamentary inquiry to look into its role in this tragedy?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we really do need some perspective on this. Over the last 30 years, most of it under federal Liberal governments, over a billion dollars have been poured into coal mining in Cape Breton. Tragedies have occurred there.
The hon. member is a member of Parliament from Cape Breton. He thinks that the only place where coal mining is dangerous is in fact outside of Cape Breton. The fact is that it is a dangerous occupation generally. The federal government has supported it in Cape Breton as well as elsewhere.
June 9, 1992

In answer to his question of yesterday, I hasten to tell him that last week we tabled 2,000 pages of evidence. The answer to every question he asked yesterday is in that evidence.
I ask him not to call for a parliamentary inquiry but to read what we have tabled.
Mr. Francis G. LeBlanc (Cape Breton Highlands-
Canso): Mr. Speaker, the Westray mine would not have opened and the lives of 26 miners would not have been lost if Clifford Frame and Curragh Resources had not received a generous deal from this government. That is the deal we want an inquiry to look into.
Canadian taxpayers now stand to lose up to $80 million as a consequence of that transaction. They want answers. Why is this government refusing to call this inquiry? What has this government got to hide?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, yesterday the hon. member and his colleague from Cape Breton made these allegations about a so-called deal for Curragh Resources and perpetrated very serious misunderstandings first of all about the consulting contract.
It was true that Curragh Resources received a consulting contract of over $6.1 million. That was to be spent over a series of years and it was. It was used by a group of engineers, accountants and managers to plan the mine, to operate the mine and to put it in place.
The hon. member wanted to make this contribution look like it was just money in somebody's pocket. In fact, those were the funds used by the consulting firm to plan and operate the mine. Dozens of people were hired and worked under that contract so he is perpetrating a very serious misunderstanding when he says that it was anything other than an ordinary transaction.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister and it is in regard to the priorities of his government.
Oral Questions
While attention is recently being focused on child sexual abuse in Martensville, Saskatchewan, the government's special advisor on child sexual abuse estimated that across the country some one-third of males and over one-half of females have been sexually abused at some time in their lives. He recommended new cost-sharing programs with the provinces to deal with this problem.
The government has ignored this advice and the plight of thousands of Canadian children. Instead, it has off-loaded billions of dollars in social programs and transfers to the provinces.
I ask the Prime Minister how much more evidence does his government need before it takes adequate and effective action to protect Canadian children from the horrors of sexual abuse?

speakeroldname: Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the allegations regarding the sexual abuse of children in the Martensville, Saskatchewan area are absolutely reprehensible, unacceptable and devastating.
There is not one person sitting here in this House nor indeed anybody in Canada who is not absolutely taken aback and disgusted with the situation.
Children are a natural asset and one of our best resources. The interesting thing has to do with regulation and child care centres across the country are under the strict jurisdiction of the provincial governments.
We have worked toward solutions for the problems with sexual abuse. The Minister Responsible for the Status of Women with her new task force on violence against women takes in problems with senior citizens as well as children. The $136 million that we brought forth in January 1991 will go toward this area.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary deals with the need for a national child care strategy. Most experts have agreed that this is what is necessary to best protect children at risk.

Oral Questions
The Minister of National Defence when he was talking about defence policy and the purchase of helicopters said that he was listening to his advisors and experts when it came to the purchase of helicopters.
I wonder why this government does not listen to its advisors and experts when it comes to child care. The National Council on Welfare, the government's own advisory agency, said: "Child care is an essential service for the majority of Canadian families with children. No strategy to combat child poverty can succeed without an adequate and affordable child care system." Why does the government not listen to its experts on child care?

speakeroldname: Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as I said earlier, the regulatory responsibility for child care is a provincial jurisdiction. It is a provincial responsibility.
I must say that the government has acted over the last few months. It ratified the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child on December 11. Also there was the announcement by the Minister of Finance of the child benefit package on February 25, which we are taking through the House today. It will put $2.1 billion into the hands of families. It will put new money into the hands of families over the next five years. The Brighter Futures program is another $500 million.
We care about children and we are putting the money where it counts.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister who is about to leave to attend the UN Conference on Environment and Development.
Yesterday in Rio the environment minister of Germany publicly committed his country to reducing carbon dioxide emissions, which are responsible for the greenhouse effect, by 25 per cent to 30 per cent by the year 2005. Yet our own government's only stated commitment is to stabilize C02 emissions even though this country emits more carbon dioxide per capita than virtually any other country.
I want to ask the Prime Minister: Will the government follow the initiative of Germany and commit to a significant reduction program of carbon dioxide emissions beyond the year 2000?

Mr. Speaker, my hon. friend may have missed an editorial in The Financial Post this morning. The headline is "Canada is a Leader on Greenhouse Gas Issue". It indicates that Canada's commitment to sign the climate change convention at the Rio summit puts reduction in gas emissions firmly on the political agenda.
It is generally recognized that for the last number of years beginning with the Montreal protocol, Canada has played a pretty progressive role in this area. Minister Charest has indicated in Rio our intention to maintain quite an impressive record for Canada.
There are things that we can do more quickly than others. This is a very important point. We are going to try to make sure that we are in the forefront of resolving the problem.

Mr. Speaker, the Prime Minister would know that the convention on climate change that Canada said it will sign is devoid of any timetable. It does not require the obligation of signing any firm measures. In other words, it is just generalized, vague statements with no strategy and no program attached. It is now up to individual nations to take the initiative.
I want to ask the Prime Minister again: Under his leadership, will the government initiate immediately consultations with industry, with NGOs, with other interested parties and with the provinces so that a concrete national strategy and timetable on carbon dioxide reductions can be put in place at the earliest opportunity?

Mr. Speaker, we would like for the convention on climate change to be viewed in the way that the green plan is for the following reasons.
I quote Mr. Tolba, the executive director of the United Nations Environmental Program who said: "Canada's green plan is a model for the whole world to study. What I really like are the goals and targets that are costed over specific periods of time. I thought the green plan was a most courageous move".
June 9, 1992

We want the same kind of thinking to go into the convention on climate change. Indeed, the Government of Canada was prepared to sign a much stronger convention on climate change. In the course of negotiations among some 175 countries, some of the provisions were diluted.
We are in the process of putting in train a program immediately post-Rio that would have the effect of building on what we will have achieved, imperfect though it is, so that some of the ideas to which the United Nations director made reference can be incorporated into the convention on climate change to give it more teeth.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
While he was perusing the editorial in The Financial Post he may have noticed the front page headline which states that Dofasco in Hamilton is about to shed another 2,250 potential jobs, added to the 937 people who last year took voluntary retirement in an industry that was supposed to be a big winner under the trade agreement.
The Prime Minister is no doubt aware that in six days the Americans are about to declare war on the Canadian steel industry. Yet yesterday his Minister for International Trade said that the Canadian government does not plan to launch its own investigation into U.S. steel even if Canadians are named in the anti-dumping investigation.
Will the Prime Minister overrule the ridiculous statement made by his Minister for International Trade yesterday and will he at least be willing to put the muscle of the government behind the fight to save the Canadian steel industry?

Mr. Speaker, I take the liberty of answering the question simply because my hon. friend asked me if, as Prime Minister, I would overrule the minister. It is not needed.
Oral Questions
If my hon. friend will consult The Toronto Star article, she will see a faithful restatement of what the minister said in regard to this very important issue.
It is the intention of the Government of Canada, with the stakeholders and with the industry, to fight what we consider to be a pernicious side-swipe action against the interests of Canada and the Canadian steel industry. We hope to carry that fight on to victory as we have under the free trade agreement in a growing number of cases.
The free trade agreement is beginning to throw off an important number of victories for Canada. We believe that this will be another one.

Mr. Speaker, what are being thrown off are the victims of free trade who are on the scrap heap of the Canadian steel industry.
The Prime Minister met with the President of the United States weeks ago and he said that he had a direct line to Washington.
If the Prime Minister has a direct line to Washington, and if he raised the steel issue with the President of the United States, why is it that as of last week according to the chairman of the Canadian Steel Producers Association, not a single American steel firm had even been contacted by the U.S. government on this issue? Who is actually telling the truth on this one?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, there is not much I can add to the Prime Minister's very pertinent response but I would like to tell the hon. member that in this particular field, counteraction against U.S. steel companies has always been a decision for the industry to take. The Minister for International Trade has made it clear that he will support the industry and the decision it takes.
More important, when the hon. member speaks about knuckling under to the Americans, we have just been informed that we have won a chapter 18 binational panel unanimous decision just rendered an hour ago on the CAMI mortgage interest question.
This was a unanimous decision in our favour, proof once again we have equality with the United States when we have a dispute and we are winning in the free trade agreement.

June 9, 1992
Oral Questions EMPLOYMENT

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Minister of Employment and Immigration.
As I mentioned earlier this afternoon and as the minister knows, there is a very successful training program conducted by a volunteer community organization in the town of Oromocto called the Jobstart Program.
It has been designed primarily in an employment scenario to teach the work ethic on a broad basis and to provide a basic level of general employment skills to young Canadians.
The Jobstart concept has been uniquely successful with the continuing employment record of more than 70 per cent since its inception. Although the Canada Employment Centre has continued to support Jobstart, unfortunately the nature of this unique program apparently does not meet the present criteria of a national program curriculum.
Does the minister and the department support the Jobstart concept of general skills training in an employment scenario and, if so, will he initiate measures to have the Jobstart criteria included as an eligible and continuing program in the general Canada employment training structure nationally?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member points to a very important aspect of the training requirements in Canada. That is why under the prosperity initiative we have included this topic for discussion by Canadians and by stakeholders in the whole economy.
As soon as these discussions are completed and we get the action plan of the steering group I hope that my department can make these programs intended for Canadian youth even more relevant.

Mr. Speaker, unemployment has nearly doubled since 1989
among youth in this country. The rate of poverty among those living alone is over 55 per cent. Drug convictions have risen by 96 per cent since 1984. Since 1984 property crime among youth has gone up 158 per cent, violent crime committed by youth by 239 per cent.
My question for the Prime Minister is this. Is it not a pretty stupid policy to be even thinking about buying more helicopters to hunt Soviet submarines in view of the real crisis in the cities of this country?

speakeroldname: Hon. Marcel Masse (Minister of National Defence):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I can inform the hon. member, if he is not familiar with national defence policy, that there are plans to purchase submarines as well as helicopters, as part of our national policy. The government has various responsibilities and one of them is national defence. Another responsibility is social policy. Yet another is economic policy. The government is responsible for allocating taxpayers' money to these various priorities. I believe Canada's defence policy is a fair response to our allies and to Canadian taxpayers.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary is simply this. In view of the serious crisis among young people in this country, is it not about time that this government gave up its $5 billion helicopter fetish in favour of the kids in this country?

speakeroldname: Hon. Marcel Masse (Minister of National Defence):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to point out that the program also contains a search and rescue component, since some of these helicopters will be used for that purpose. I suppose a few years from now, the same member will accuse the government of shirking its responsibility to Canadians if it fails to acquire the necessary equipment to provide for research and rescue operations in this country.
The government cannot afford to bow to the pressures of the media. It must have a sound policy, and it does.
June 9, 1992

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Justice. Many Albertans are deeply concerned with the application of the Young Offenders Act.
Is the minister, perhaps with the Solicitor General of Canada, prepared to undertake consultations with provincial governments on the application of this act? Briefly the objective would be to have provincial governments issue clear instructions to Crown prosecutors and judges to deal with these serious crimes in a firmer manner. Would the minister be prepared to consider that kind of initiative?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member is quite right in recognizing that the implementation of the Young Offenders Act regime requires the co-operation of three levels of government. We have ongoing consultations with the provinces now with respect to further amendments to the Young Offenders Act.
As the hon. member will know, the Government of Canada prosecutes young offenders only in the territories. I have developed a prosecutor's desk book which I will be discussing with my federal prosecutors in a couple of weeks precisely to put into place the kind of guidelines that the hon. member would seek in applying the law in this area and others.
I will be pleased to review the nature of the consultations we are having with the provinces. The deputy ministers will be meeting in a couple of weeks to prepare for the federal-provincial-territorial meeting of ministers this fall and I will ensure that that subject is dealt with at those federal-provincial meetings.

Mr. Speaker, with reference to the steel issue raised in the United States, the minister has said that there is a dispute settlement mechanism in place which will ultimately resolve the issue.
Oral Questions
He knows that in the meantime Canadian steel producers will be seriously harmed by U.S. trade actions while the panel decision is awaited and the prospect is that Canadian producers will lose further market share during that time.
He knows also that under the existing agreement it pays U.S. steel producers to launch trade remedy actions even if it is likely they will lose under the dispute settlement mechanism.
Is the government taking the occasion of the negotiations of a North American free trade agreement to correct the anomalies in the free trade agreement with the United States? Is it taking the occasion of the NAFTA talks to renegotiate those anomalies in the free trade agreement?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do find it very disturbing. The hon. member admits he thinks this country could not win a dispute with the United States on the steel matter. I do not know why he is so defeatist.
Essentially what I was saying in response to the steel matter was that the Minister for International Trade will support our steel industry with regard to that dispute.
I did not say, and he has not said, that we are going to go into a chapter 18 or chapter 19 mechanism. However, he has not ruled out "initiating an anti-dumping or countervail claim".
What I was speaking about was another chapter 18 decision which was just tabled about an hour ago. It indicates that non-mortage interest is now to be included in the CAMI instance and it will have a very good influence on the upcoming Honda decision. All of this is positive proof that the free trade dispute settlement mechanism is working and the over-all agreement is working.

Mr. Speaker, that was not what I was asking. I was not asking about an automobile dispute resolution; I was asking about the steel issue. Let me try it once more.
Back in 1988 the Prime Minister said that his highest priority in the trade agreement was to end "the threat from U.S. protectionists who harass and restrict our imports through the misuse of trade remedy law".

I would like to review the various steps that this government has taken in eroding family programs, particularly programs for children.

The second step was that the government introduced the child tax credit. Of course, as it is wont to do, it said this was a way to transfer benefits to those most in need. We heard that theme again today. not. It recognized that as a society we had a social responsibility to help care for the next generation.

He acknowledged to the women of Canada in particular that this was a priority need and a priority of his government. However, once elected of course each time the promise was broken and this was the lowest priority.

The Liberal Party.

The Liberal Party unfortunately, my friend, does not propose that.
Most working families will have to continue to use unreliable babysitting arrangements. Let us look at those who have higher incomes and who are paying taxes. What happens to them? What does this government provide to parents that stay at home? We understand there is a new-maybe it is not so new-family caucus now that is reinventing the traditional old family values. The government did make a token gesture for a parent that stays home to care for children. This is extremely important work that should be highly valued. What do

they get? They get a token $213 a year for children under seven. I say it is a gross insult.

We travelled this country many times and heard from so many groups the stories of what was happening to kids and the tremendous stress on families, particularly in the poorest provinces of Canada.
We recommended specific suggestions for a comprehensive national child care program. It was not as rich as I would have liked, but it was a lot better than what we have now. I would like to go back to one of the main points of focus of Bill C-80 which is to establish the new child tax benefit. When it was proposed in the 1992 budget, it was said that this tax would be simpler, fairer and more generous. It is none of these. The child benefit is supposed to help low income families escape from poverty by providing a child benefit which will supplement the minimum wages if they should go off welfare and find a job that pays minimum wages.

There are very few jobs around and most of those only pay minimum wages which gives the parents practically no advantage over their present situation. I do not have to say how much it costs to raise children today.

The child benefit is based on what I would call an 18th century philosophy of welfare, which is of course the typical Tory philosophy on social welfare programs generally. It establishes two classes of the poor.
First of all, we have the working poor. They are the deserving poor. They are the poor who will get an extra $500 for their children if they go out to work. Then there are those who are on welfare. They are the second class poor. They are the poorest of the poor. At the same time that this government is taking the family allowance away in this bill, we have to remember it is also taking away from low income families co-op housing programs which are desperately needed to have an affordable quality shelter for Canadians. The Conservative philosophy of partially deindexing social programs, which incidentally has already reduced increases in old age pensions, also applies to these child benefits. It means the value of benefits will go down each succeeding year. Deindexing is a secretive Tory plot to gradually reduce the value of benefits. By the year 2000 many of these benefits will be practically out of existence or they will have very little value.
As New Democrats, we would have a very different approach. My time is almost up so I do not have time to outline this in detail. We believe that the first thing we must do to counteract poverty is to make every effort to create jobs. Full employment should be a major priority of government.
This means we must have government intervention. We must have government leadership. We cannot tie unemployment to the rate of inflation and interest rates and allow the unemployed to be the victims of a reverse
economic situation. It means that we must have not only jobs but we must have jobs with decent rates of pay and pay equity. Along with that must be quality, affordable child care, non-profit child care. This is the best antidote to poverty and to chronic welfare dependency.
We must maintain our universal social programs. We must reinstate family allowances so that children of all families will be recognized and so all of us who pay taxes will be contributing to the next generation. After all, these are the children who will be paying the old age pensions for their parents as they get older.
Children must have the care, love and opportunities to grow and develop in health. Children may not vote, I tell the Conservatives, but they must not be ignored. Canada must eradicate child poverty by the year 2000. This is not going to be done with platitudes and words. Jobs, decent family incomes and quality child care are the pillars to a better future for this and future generations of Canadian children.

Mr. Speaker, I thank the member for allowing me to elaborate on those two points. If he looks back at the "blues" he will see that when I mentioned it we had been-it was in the past tense-in favour, or would have liked to have seen family allowances raised. It was Stanley Knowles who was one of the earliest activists and advocates for family allowances. Initially we saw this in those times and that is what I was referring to as being one way that you could share the burden, if you like, or the cost of raising Canada's children.
I do not happen to have children but I feel very strongly that I would like to contribute through the tax system to the raising of all-I cannot afford all-of Canada's children but certainly we should be contributing just as much as parents who are paying for their own children. That, I think, is a social responsibility. I was referring to that really in conceptual terms.
Over the last two platforms that we have had, we realized it was not possible at this time to raise family allowances. We have always said that any universal program is balanced out a bit through our tax system because those who pay more taxes, and the same goes for the old age pension, get the universal payment but they are taxed more for it.
I think the other point had to do with the cheques going to the mother. I know there were many women who spoke to this point a few years ago when we had hearings on child and family benefits. In a way I thought it was a bit sexist because there are many fathers who are also the main parenting person in families.
Perhaps we should not necessarily hold to that virtue. Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have the opportunity to participate in this debate on Bill C-80 which proposes to merge the family allowance program, the refundable child tax credit, and non-refundable dependant child credit into the new child tax benefit program and the children's special allowances program.
As members will recall, the proposed child tax benefit program was announced by my colleague, the Minister of Finance, in his February 25 budget speech.
There is no doubt that benefit programs for children and their families touch all of us in one way or another. As the Minister of National Health and Welfare said when introducing Brighter Futures a call to action on behalf of Canada's children: "We can only build a brighter future for Canada by cherishing all our children".
I am very pleased that these two ministers and colleagues of mine have recently taken the type of actions they have, not only in developing this program but in developing other programs that support and benefit children.
These two ministers have been especially cognizant of the needs of families and they have listened very carefully to their colleagues in caucus. All of us appreciate very much the way they work with us to bring these changes about, particularly the ones we are talking about today.
In assessing the importance of this legislation I believe it would be useful to take a few minutes to look at what has gone before, to reflect on the evolution of federal child benefit programs, which began modestly after the First World War and took a considerable step forward with the family allowances program in the 1940s.
We will see a logical progression which brings us to the new child tax benefit program.
The concept of a family benefit related to children goes back as far as 1918 when an amendment to the Income War Tax Act introduced the child tax exemption of $200 for each child under the age of 16.
The importance of this step lies in the fact that it recognized in principle the income needs of families with children.

June 9, 1992
Government Orders
In 1927 the child tax exemption was increased to $500 and extended to all children under 21. It was also at this time that the equivalent to married exemption was introduced.
These tax measures related to children continued to evolve in the twenties and thirties and were converted to tax credits in the early forties. At the same time the idea of family allowance began to surface. It was first raised in this House in February 1929 when a member made a motion to the effect that: "The question of granting family allowances should be studied".
The House of Commons select standing committee did consider the question of family allowances in 1929. Unfortunately the Depression of the 1930s, followed by World War II, postponed further consideration of such a scheme until the early 1940s when it was studied by the House of Commons reconstruction committee.
The work of the committee was guided by a policy which fell into three broad divisions: demobilisation and re-establishment, economic and employment aspects, and human well-being and health. The notion of a family allowance was seen to relate to all three of these areas. It would provide cash regularly to families who needed it most, creating a continuous demand for basic necessities which would encourage production and steady employment.
The federal government also began to think about a long-term social security plan for the country. This had been spurred on to some extent by the release in November 1942 of a report to the British Parliament by Sir William Beveridge titled Social Insurance and Allied Services. The Beveridge report proposed, among other things, a children's allowance to counter what its author saw as the failure of the wage system to take account of family size.
In December 1942 the Canadian ministers of pensions and health asked Dr. Leonard Marsh to develop a plan on social security. Dr. Marsh's Report on Social Security for Canada, popularly known as the Marsh report, was presented to this House in March 1943. Dr. Marsh believed that one of the major causes of poverty was the fact that wage earners with large families had insufficient earnings and that since wages took no account of family size the state had a legitimate role to play in adjusting disposable income to reflect family size.
We must remember that there were few social welfare programs in Canada in 1943. Assistance for needy families most often came from churches and private organizations. Although all provinces had introduced mother's allowances programs for women and children who were alone and in need these programs were so restrictive that they often excluded the very people that they were supposed to help.
Over all, the payment of a benefit on behalf of children was seen as an investment in the future of the country and particularly in the country's most valuable asset, its children.
The government announced its intention to introduce a family allowance in the Speech from the Throne in January 1944:
The family and the home are the foundation of national life. To aid in ensuring a minimum of well-being to the children of the nation and to help gain for them a closer approach to equality of opportunity in the battle of life, you will be asked to approve a measure making provision for family allowances.
Although the family allowance program was payable to all families with children regardless of income its main focus was to improve equity by assisting children in lower income families. This is clear in the statement made by the Prime Minister of the day in introducing the bill to Parliament. He said:
The adoption of family allowances means the recognition of the right of children of poor parents to what is already recognized as the right of children whose parents are in more fortunate circumstances -
Already this Parliament has recognized that, with respect to families, there is an obligation upon the state to assist in the upbringing of children. This has been done in the interests of the parents and the family itself, but more particularly in the interests of the children. But, up to the present time, that obligation has been recognized only with respect to the more fortunate in our country, those who already have an income large enough to be taxable to entitle them to exemptions according to the number of children in the family. In other words, where the need has been least it has already been recognized. The purpose of this bill is to recognize a similar obligation where the need is obviously greater than it is in the other cases.
It is interesting to note that although the debate was lengthy, and a look through the Hansards of the day indicates that it was also rather spirited, when the vote was finally taken there was not a single dissenting voice. Thus, in 1945 Canada had established a program by which the federal government could provide a supplement to family income. This was seen as a necessary and positive step forward in spreading the cost of raising children more equitably over the whole population.
June 9, 1992

Furthermore, this new benefit was intended to help equalize opportunity for all children insofar as the state was justified and obligated to do so.
The family allowance was established as a universal program. It was believed that providing the allowance to all children was the simplest and cheapest way of providing a supplementary family income. However, there was to be no duplication with the child tax credit. Therefore, higher income families who were eligible for the child tax credit would return some or all of the allowance at tax time.
At the same time, the family allowance provided a measure of equity to families whose incomes were below the tax paying level and therefore did not benefit from the tax exemption for children. In essence, we had a system of tax credits for dependants that gave equivalent benefits to all income classes, supplemented by family allowances which were income tested through the tax system.
However, the system that was required to adjust the family allowances to the income tax allowances for children proved to be unreasonably cumbersome for everyone-taxpayers, employers and tax administrators alike-in an era when computers were still the stuff of science fiction. Therefore, the tax on family allowances was repealed in 1947, tax credits were abandoned, and tax exemptions were reinstituted.
Over the years, further changes were made to the tax system with respect to families with children. In 1972 the child care expense deduction was introduced, recognizing the child care costs incurred by working parents. However, the Family Allowances Act was not changed significantly until 1973.
Interest in a new direction and emphasis for the income security system in the late 1960s and early 1970s resulted from a growing dissatisfaction with what was seen as a large and costly social security system co-existing with a disturbing incidence of poverty. A number of studies revealed a high degree of inequality in the distribution of income.
For example, the Senate committee's 1971 report, Poverty in Canada, emphasized the plight of the working poor who it said numbered close to two million in 1967. The report denounced the existing social security system for not providing more assistance to, and I quote, "that
Government Orders
vast army in the labour force whose income is grossly insufficient".
Thus, on second reading of the 1973 bill on family allowances, the then Minister of National Health and Welfare said:
The original family allowances program was introduced for the purpose of giving a maximum measure of income support to families to help ease the financial burden of bringing up children and to provide a measure of equal opportunity for children regardless of a family's economic situation. The objective of the new family allowance program is to provide a supplement to the income of Canadian families in such a way that those with the greatest need will receive the greatest benefit.
This approach provided the direction for subsequent child benefit measures adopted during the 1970s and 1980s and the greater focusing of efforts and benefits on low income families. I believe it is important to take note of the fact that while the new Family Allowances Act of 1973 maintained the broad concept of universality the selectivity of taxing the benefit was fully supported by this House.
The Minister of National Health and Welfare of the day acknowledged that the new program was designed to provide greater benefits to families with the lowest income. He said:
By taxing family allowances we will bring about a substantial degree of selectivity in the amount of the benefit because a large part of the allowance will remain in the hands of those who need it most -the lower income families who do not earn sufficient income to pay taxes or who earn just enough to be taxed at the lowest marginal tax rate. On the other hand, families in the higher income tax brackets will receive a benefit that progressively reduces as income rises.
Child benefits were again restructured in 1978 in response to the concern that there continued to be a disproportionate benefit to higher income families. For example, tax exemptions and deductions were of little or no value to low income families, many of whom had no taxable income.
To address this concern a new child tax benefit, the refundable child tax credit, was introduced and the level of family allowance benefits was reduced. The child tax credit program was designed primarily to provide assistance to low and modest income families. It provided a maximum benefit of $200 per child per year and the benefit was reduced for families with income above $18,000.

Government Orders
During the 1980s a number of measures were taken to better target benefits to lower income families who needed them most. For example, the child tax credit was increased in 1982, 1987, 1989 and again in 1990, bringing it to a total of $559.
In November 1986 the government began prepaying two-thirds of the child tax credit to lower income families. In 1990 an additional $200 supplement was provided for children under seven years whose parents were not claiming the child care expense deduction. The limit on this deduction was raised by $4,000 for children six years and under and for children with special needs.
I think my hon. colleagues will agree that we can see a certain progression in the development of children's benefits in this country. When the family allowance program was introduced in 1945 it was done in recognition of the need to provide equality of opportunity to all Canadian children. It was introduced at a time when families were expected to deal personally with almost every contingency, no matter how serious.
If assistance was required in desperate circumstances it was expected that relatives, friends, neighbours, the community and the church would provide it. It was only after all these avenues had been explored and exhausted that a family received carefully rationed public charity, which incidentally was rarely in the form of cash.
The introduction in 1945 of family allowances, together with the unemployment insurance program, marked the beginning of the planning of a comprehensive social security system in Canada. With the creation of this new family benefit the state recognized and accepted its role and responsibility in sharing more equitably across the whole Canadian community the cost of raising our children.
We must continue today not only to share this responsibility but to ensure that those most in need receive the most assistance. This is the direction in which child benefit programs have been moving in Canada, and the proposed child tax benefit is a major step along this path.
The new child benefit addresses the changing circumstances of Canadian families in several ways. It simplifies the present patchwork of programs and benefits. Mr. Speaker, if you were following the long list of complicated plans we have in the present tax system you would agree that simplification should be a major goal of this government in every part of its endeavours.
The new benefit provides a supplement to the earnings of low income working families and it provides a greater responsiveness to individual family situations.
The key element of this program that makes it so different from all other programs we have had is that it is the first time in Canada that a social support program is delivered through the tax system according to income and is universally available to everyone. I admit that not everyone gets it every year, but it is available without application simply by filing an income tax form.
I would also like to add that a number of speakers on this bill have suggested that families with incomes between $30,000 and $50,000 will receive an increase of only $4 a month or $50 a year. credit which would actually benefit all needy families working or unable to find work.

Mr. Speaker, occasionally in this House we debate legislation that touches the very fabric of Canadian society. Bill C-80, an act to implement the proposed child tax benefit is just such an act. It reflects the fundamental Canadian tradition of redistributing scarce resources for the general benefit of Canadians, particularly our children.
In the white paper on the child benefit, the Minister of National Health and Welfare noted that Canada's future well-being and prosperity depend on our children. They
Government Orders
are our greatest asset. It follows then that we must attend to their current well-being to ensure they lead happy and fulfilling productive lives. We must strengthen our efforts now.
Assistance to children is a continuing priority of the Government of Canada. This past December, the Prime Minister announced that Canada had formally ratified the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. The convention is aimed at protecting the rights of children around the world.
The Brighter Futures initiative announced recently by the Minister of National Health and Welfare further confirms this government's commitment to children, their parents, and care givers. The initiative is a series of steps we can take now in order to achieve a brighter tomorrow for Canada and our children.
The child tax benefit is one of those steps. When implemented, it will simplify the tax system and streamline and substantially enrich the government's support for families with children. Over the next five years the child tax benefit will provide $2.5 billion in increased child assistance.
This is a substantial amount especially given the pressures on the government's fiscal position. As a result, Canadian families of low and modest means will be better able to meet the challenges of their daily lives.
Let me emphasize that Canada's assistance to families with children is already among the best in the world. Indeed, assistance to children has long been a cornerstone of Canada's social commitment to its people.
Currently, the federal government spends $4.5 billion a year on the three largest and most direct forms of support to families with children. Those include the family allowances, the child credit and the refundable child tax credit.
Moreover, additional federal support to Canadian families is provided through the goods and services tax credit, the child care expense deduction and maternity and parental benefits under the unemployment insurance program. Under the Canada Assistance Plan the federal government also cost shares expenditures by the provinces and territories on social assistance and services, including subsidized child care.
