To provide the context for the child tax benefit, I want to explain briefly the three major federal programs of support for Canadian families.
The family allowance, introduced almost 50 years ago in 1945, is familiar to most Canadians. Often referred to as the baby bonus, it provides $1.9 billion a year of net federal benefits to about 3.7 million Canadian families with children under the age of 18. Payments are about $35 per child a month for a total of $419 per year and are generally paid to mothers. To assist the government to control expenditures and better target resources, the payments are taxable and are partially or fully recovered from high income Canadians.
The child credit is an annual deduction from the federal tax owing of $71 for each dependent child 18 years or under at the end of the tax year. For third and subsequent children the credit is increased to $142. The accumulated net benefit of the child credit to Canadian families is $400 million. The credit has existed in one form or another since 1947.
Finally, to increase assistance to families with low and modest incomes, the refundable child tax credit was introduced in 1979. The credit has a maximum value of $601 and is provided for each dependent child age 18 or under at the end of the tax year. As well, a supplement of up to $213 per child under age seven is provided to families not claiming child care expenses. These benefits are reduced for families with incomes exceeding $25,921 per year. Total federal payments under the refundable child tax credit amount to $2.2 billion per year.
The 1992 report of the United Nations Development Program ranked Canada first in the world on a range of factors assessing a country's human development and quality of life. The federal programs I have outlined have contributed significantly in this regard.
Nevertheless, difficult living conditions remain a fact of life for many low income Canadian families. For these children we must do more to ensure that their parents have adequate resources to meet their basic needs. We must enhance our support to ensure that these children are raised in conditions that promote healthy development.
The child tax benefit will assist us to provide that enhanced support. In a moment I will explain how. However, I first want to focus briefly on the problems that necessitate its implementation.
As Canada's major programs of assistance for Canadian families have grown over the years, shortcomings have appeared. Accordingly, the government has been urged to improve this patchwork system of child benefits. In particular, two parliamentary committees, social policy groups outside the government and many individual Canadians have identified the following faults with our current system.
First, benefits are delivered piecemeal in three different ways and at different times of the year. This delivery patchwork is confusing for many Canadians because each program has different eligibility criteria. As well, for
600,000	higher income Canadians, family allowances must be partially or fully repaid to the government when they file their income tax returns.
Second, benefits are not targeted adequately. In particular, because family allowances are recovered on the basis of individual incomes, families with similar total incomes may receive different levels of benefits. Family income is a better basis to direct assistance to children most in need.
Third, independent support creates barriers to work for low income families. These families are faced with employment related expenses and a possible reduction in social assistance when they choose to work.
Finally, the delay in the delivery of the refundable tax credit is difficult in many modest income families. While it represents more than half of the federal child benefit, for many families it fails to meet their immediate needs. For example, although they must pay for the child's needs every month, parents may have to wait a full year to receive the full credit. As a result, many families sacrifice part of their benefits by resorting to tax discounters to obtain badly needed cash.
The proposed child tax benefit is designed to address these structural faults and strengthen the federal support for Canadian families. It responds to the recom-
June 9, 1992

mendations for change that have been urged upon the government.
The benefit is streamlined, responsible and better targeted. It provides enriched benefits that will be delivered on a more timely and less complicated basis. The increased benefit is a social dividend financed by the spending cuts the government announced in the 1992 budget.
Canadians believe that fiscal progress should result in increased assistance to Canadian families. Our government agrees. Over the next five years, the proposed child tax benefit will increase assistance to Canadian families by an average of $400 million a year from $4.5 billion to $4.9 billion.
Under the new system, the basic amount of the benefit will be $1,020 per year for each child. The current annual supplement of $213 will be continued for each child under the age of seven. Where no child care expenses are deducted, a $75 supplement will be provided for the third and additional children.
Low income families will also be eligible to receive an earned income supplement of up to $500. This means that low income families will receive up to $1,733 for their first child and up to $1,233 for each subsequent child. The child tax benefit will be provided to all families with annual incomes up to $67,000 per year.
For families with three or more children, the benefit cut-off will be higher than $67,000. The basic benefit will be reduced at a rate of 5 per cent of family net income over $25,921 for families with two or more children, and at a lower rate of 2.5 per cent for families with one child. The average annual benefits for families with incomes below $50,000 will be $250 higher.
As with other elements of the tax system, the child tax benefit will be automatically indexed to changes in prices in excess of 3 per cent. However, as in the case with the child tax credit which has been enriched five times since 1984, the benefits will be reviewed over time and adjusted as fiscal conditions permit. These previous enrichments have ensured that the level of federal child benefits paid to low income families have more than kept pace with inflation.
Clearly under the new system these benefits will be more fairly and effectively targeted than under the current system.

The greatest benefits will go to low and modest income families. About 80 per cent of the total increase in benefits will be directed to families with incomes below $40,000 per year.
Single parent families face particular difficulties due to their combined responsibilities of earning a living and caring for their children. To further assist single parents the equivalent to married credit will be continued for their first child. This is worth an average of $1,445 in reduced federal and provincial taxes for many single parents.
The government designed the child tax benefit to reinforce the incentives for low income parents to participate in the work force. Often they face financial barriers, such as employment related expenses and possible reductions in social benefits, which preclude them from seeking employment. Accordingly, a new earned income supplement of up to $500 will be available to working families who receive little or no social assistance.
I want to emphasize that the new child tax benefit will be progressive. Benefit limits will be determined according to family income not individual income. This means that families at a given income level will be treated the same regardless of the number of income earners. This will better ensure that the assistance be directed according to family needs. The new approach will also be simpler.

With all the money the government is reaping from here and giving there why does it not have the wherewithal to contribute at least some of it to the food banks? That is where more and more Canadian children are finding themselves.
It is due to this government that Canadians find themselves in want of the basic necessities of existence. When this government took office there was one, and I stress one, food bank in Canada. Today there are 292. It is time for this government to bear the responsibility for the impact of its destructive economic policies and put its support behind Canadians.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George-Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to enter into this debate. I believe there is just a brief amount of time left before this House has the opportunity to pass judgment on this legislation.
We are debating a very important measure here today that was introduced by way of Bill C-80, which the government introduced as part of its budget procedures. It has been sold by this government to a large degree as an attempt to ease and simplify a very important component of many of our social programs in the country, namely the child benefit program.
It has been clear from many of the questions and comments raised in this House, as early as Question Period today, and from the comments from members on this side of the House, that this debate is about more than just a piece of legislation to arrange the regulatory and financial measures to provide the kind of benefits to families in this country that people have rightfully come to expect from the Government of Canada. It was brought on by the approach this government has taken in this legislation and in terms of many of the comments members of the government have made over the past little while.

Government Orders
If we examine some of the background of this particular legislation we can see that since the Conservative government came into office in 1984 it has cut family benefits dramatically. It killed the old income tax deduction of around $710 per child under age 18 and brought in a tax credit worth far less. It is now worth around $71 per child.
In the 1992 federal budget, the most recent one, the government announced an end to the existing family benefits, to be replaced with an extremely targeted so-called child benefit. The new benefit consists of a basic benefit of $1,020 per child with benefits being reduced at a threshold of net income of around $25,000. The bill and the measures that the government introduced went on to deal with a number of other issues in that regard.
What is wrong with the Conservative approach on this? We heard recently of what they call the family caucus or the family compact as it is more likely called. The vision of Canada that we see coming from some members on the government side is very right wing. What we are starting to see is that some members on the government side do not like the direction their own government is going. This is causing some dissent and members are obviously lobbying to try and have their agenda met.
While the Conservatives argue and want us to believe that this new child benefit is simpler, fairer and more generous, it is none of the above. The system means an end to universal family allowances and thus the end to the principle that the task of raising children is recognized in all families regardless of income level. The family allowance recognizes that all children, rich and poor-an important point-are of equal value to our society and its universality ensures that it is non-stigmatizing.
In the whole debate we have had from time to time in this country, this government has very surreptitiously, most people would argue, eroded the concept of universality in Canada. It would rather have us line up at the welfare offices and go down to the United Way to try and get help for our families. That is not the approach that we want to take in this country. It is a vindictive, nasty approach in a particularly sensitive and important field:
the whole question of the family support and support for children across this country.
For many women the family allowance was the only money they received in recognition of their unpaid work and valuable contribution to society. For many women the family allowance was their only independent source of income.
As well, the government is suggesting that the new system of child benefits is a simplified system that would make low income families better off. It always sounds good, does it not? The new system is comprised, it says, of four sets of benefits as opposed to the five in the old system.
The new system is so complicated that the government, not the individual families, will have to calculate the benefits. What is created, I suppose, is an additional bureaucracy for administering many of these programs. The government has gone about developing this, as I have said, in a vindictive and backward way in the delivery of these programs.
Let me quote from a document prepared by some of my colleagues. It is a very revealing document in terms of just what is behind this question. It raises the point of fairness. It states:
The new system is the first government benefit which distinguishes between the "deserving" and "undeserving" poor. The $500 earned income supplement will add $500 to working poor families earning between about $10,000 and $20,921. This was described as an added incentive for social assistance recipients to "get out of the welfare trap". However, with child care costing between $6,000 and $12,000 per year, an extra $500 will not go very far.
That is an important point which was made by a previous speaker. All of us see it in our ridings, single parents, in particular women, attempting to get jobs. Who is going to take care of the child at home? We need day care programs as well as other programs. This government made a commitment at one time for a national day care system which it is now backing down from. We have seen many single parents attempt to get jobs, but how can we blame them if they do not when we add up the whole cost of day care and transportation. They cannot afford it.
In conclusion, this is legislation we do not need to see in this House. I am proud that our party did so much work on this issue. Let us make sure that the government members on the other side get the message tonight during this vote.
June 9, 1992

speakeroldname: Mr. Steve Butland (Sault Ste. Marie) moved
speechtext:
that Bill C-327, an act to assist employees to purchase a controlling shareholding in the corporation that employs them and to amend the Income Thx Act in consequence thereof, be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Economics envelope.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the concurrence of the House to proceed with the full hour. It was much anticipated, therefore, I would prefer the full hour to just a half hour of debate.
The bill is C-327 and if I could read it into the record:
An act to assist employees to purchase a controlling shareholding in
the corporation that employs them and to amend the Income Thx Act
in consequence thereof.
It takes a long time for a bill to get to this point. It is particularly gratifying and I feel very happy and privileged to be able to speak to the bill at long last at second reading.
I believe the ability of employees to not only work in an environment but to perhaps own the working environment would be a step forward for the country. It is a much delayed step forward for the country since many other countries in the world already have legislation in place that allows employees to become majority shareholders in the company for which they work. We believe it is a democracy that can stretch from the shop floor to the boardrooms of the company.
In order for the bill to get to this point, it is indeed a trying circumstance. Certainly there have been several members who have written me personally and suggested that the bill would be out of order since only a government can propose a tax bill. Fortunately the legal counsel has indicated to me and to all those who might care that
June 9, 1992

the bill does not in fact increase income tax. It may in fact decrease income tax and therefore it is perfectly legitimate for a private member's bill to come forward as it has done.
May I suggest that this bill was supposed to be a forerunner rather than an after-runner to the Algoma Steel Corporation employee buy-out that has now been consummated and hopefully will lead to a positive future for Algoma Steel.
Given that fact it is unfortunate but nevertheless it points out that a corporation the size of Algoma can be purchased by the employees not without the consideration of, in this case, a parent company without the consideration and the spearheading by the United Steel Workers of America, not without the involvement of the Ontario government, not without the involvement of the banks of this country, and I must say not without the involvement of the federal government.
I will say in their participation in this restructuring and reprofiling of Algoma Steel, the federal government was reticent and hesitant and came in yelling and screaming, but in the end it did participate and I salute it for that. We do appreciate the fact that the federal government was an integral part in the final restructuring of the plan and I think the community of Sault Ste. Marie would also send out that thank-you.
Nevertheless, I want to say that this type of legislation has come its time. Rather than dealing with the issue on a crisis by crisis situation, or putting out a fire here in Ontario, or one in Manitoba, or one in British Columbia as there is every possibility that the governments of this country will have to face, rather than doing it in a piecemeal way, let us have a strategy in place so that we can deal with companies on the verge of closure, on the verge of bankruptcy, or in other cases where sometimes the parent company says: "This company that we own is not making enough profits and we wish to cut the ties with the company". In all of those cases and all of those scenarios it would be much better if we had legislation in place so that we can deal with it in an orderly fashion, rather than dealing with them on a one by one situation as in Algoma.
I want to point out, that this bill will give tax credits to the employers, to the employees, and to the lending institutions so that all the participants can become involved and form a partnership in the new company. It
Private Members' Business
does not pit one individual versus another. I think that is a key instrument of this bill.
In speaking to the cost of the bill, I want to say that if you deal with a situation like Algoma, it has cost the Ontario government millions of dollars. It will cost the federal government millions of dollars. It will cost the employees, collectively, millions of dollars: $2.89 per hour for every employee in the corporation.
There are sacrifices to be made by individuals and governments, and in this case so too for the banks. If the government were to say that this bill would be too costly, I suggest that the alternative is not acceptable to anyone. The alternative, if Algoma were to close there would be 5,500 to 6,500 affected, depending on the employment level at any one time. The cost to all levels of government-federal, provincial and municipal-would be astronomical. First of all, everyone would go on UI, and afterward, unfortunately, many would be on the social assistance program, which would be very difficult for the municipality, under terrible duress already. They just could not handle it, the impact upon a community like Sault Ste. Marie with that number of people being laid off in one fell swoop.
It was pointed out that a city of 80,000 population would decrease by 20,000. I think you can apply this scenario to any community, any constituency, any industry, small, medium or large across this country. May I suggest that from day to day to day we read in the newspapers that "another company is on the verge of", "another company has already closed".
This legislation would allow the people who work within that company-the owners, the employers, the employees and everyone-to get involved together, to take one last crack at making a company viable yet again. It is proven in the United States, Italy, Israel, Germany, and many countries across the world that employee ownership can make an unsuccessful company viable, successful and profitable.
All of us may be faced with that scenario in our constituencies. That is why I hope that all parties will set aside whatever differences they may have and see fit to support this bill that again speaks of new partnerships, really unknown to this point. In our community the unions, the two levels of government, the banks, the employer, and the employees, got together and made it

Private Members' Business
work. We are hopeful for the future. May I suggest once again that it was an ad hoc dealing with the situation rather than a strategic plan that can deal with the situation right across the country.
We suggest that government has to have a role. If it is to have a role, why not in the best form that we know, and that is the form of legislation? Put it in a legislative form.
The provincial governments in Manitoba and Ontario have what I believe is legislation in place or about to come into place whereby rather than acting against what I am proposing would be complementary to what I am proposing. This federal legislation could be put into place and not seriously take away or detract from provincial legislation. I think that should be pointed out here.
The corporations in the province can opt in or can opt out of the regulations in Bill C-327. I think that is important to point out as well. We are not stepping on jurisdictional toes by putting this forward.
If the company is allowed to proceed with this, it gives not only the community new life, but it also gives the company new life. It gives the community new life as it did in our community. It brought people together. It gives time for the community to, hopefully, diversify. It is a lesson for Sault Ste. Marie and it would be a lesson for many other communities. Kapuskasing is another recent example that was dealt with by the Ontario government, the employer and the employees. It was a totally different set of circumstances, handled totally differently by the governments. Why not standardize it? Getting back to my point, it gives an opportunity for the communities to realize that you cannot depend on one industry for your future. You must diversify. I do not want to paint this as a time-buyer, but it does serve that purpose.
I want to say that six or eight months ago when I was pursuing this without any bill in place, I asked the Minister of Finance and the Minister of Industry, Science and Technology in Question Period if they supported the concept of employee ownership. They both replied that they did but "it was up to him as to whether or not this government would support that. We do not
know what you want us to support. We like the idea, but we do not know what you are asking specifically".
The specifics are now there. We are asking for changes in the Income Ihx Act. I think everyone puts their arms up in a bit of trepidation about taking on the Income Tax Act. I want to say that in the United States the handling of this legislation is much more convoluted than I am suggesting in this bill. It impacts on a whole series of statutes, regulations and income tax acts which I will not bore anyone with by reading, but I want to assure you that this is a much more simplistic way of dealing with the problem rather than the American style. I want to say that what the American Income Tax Act does is it facilitates and motivates people to participate.
I am sure the government will suggest that we have some legislation in place that will assist, but there is no facilitator and no motivator. It really gives no one the impetus to go forward and really pursue it.
With regard to Bill C-327, it would not be my first wish to have ministerial override, but I do not want to be politically naive. Perhaps it is a good idea in a private members' bill to say: "The minister has to be convinced that this is a viable option for this small, medium or large company". I think it is important that the government has that option. As I said, it would not be my choice but, under the circumstances, I think it is appropriate that I put that in.
I should also suggest, and I have mentioned it once before, that it should not be only for companies that are in dire circumstances like Algoma with $800 million in debt. Those are the most dire of circumstances. Perhaps we can address small, medium and large corporations, industries or businesses that have not reached that stage yet, where there is potential for addressing situations before they reach that degree of severity of economic hardship. The bill suggests a way of getting that under way is that at least 50 per cent of the employees have to sign a petition saying: "Let us take a look at this possibility". That is the way of getting it started. It starts on the shop floor with the employees and it ends with the minister. It runs the whole gamut, I suppose, of the political or non-political spectrum from grassroots to the people who make the decisions in this country.
June 9, 1992

I hope that it can appeal to employees and I hope it can appeal to the government.
How common is employee ownership in the United States? As of 1987 it was estimated about 7,000 to 8,000 U.S. companies had employee stock ownership plans with approximately eight million worker participants. About 1,000 to 1,500 of these companies are 51 per cent to 100 per cent owned by their workers, who probably number around one million. Perhaps as many as another million workers are in firms that are 20 per cent to 50 per cent employee owned. About 100 to 250 employee stock ownership plan firms are the result of worker buy-outs of failing companies or successful subsidiaries of large concerns.
As far as political endorsation and non-political en-dorsation, I am glad to say that our local chamber supports it. I am glad to say the Canadian Chamber of Commerce is actively looking at the bill now and I hope to get the financial institutions to take a look at it because, as members know, this bill will come before us again in the fall. I hope in the summer months to build up some national support because I think it is a cause that can be readily supported by all areas and sometimes provide a new direction. I think everyone knows a new direction is required because perhaps what we are doing right at this present moment is not that successful.
Far be it from me to read endorsations from the United States, but I want to say in the United States as unlikely an endorser of this motive was ex-President Ronald Reagan. I am not so sure I should say this but I can use it to my own advantage. I quote:
Could there be anything but widespread misery where a privileged few control the nation's wealth, while millions laboured for a pittance, and millions more were desperate for want of employment? It should be clear to everyone that the nation's steadfast policy should afford every American of working age a realistic opportunity to acquire the ownership and control of some meaningful form of property in a growing national economy.
I think the ex-President is saying: "Yes, I endorse employee ownership".
A more likely endorser was a gentleman now deceased on the opposite end of the spectrum, Hubert Humphrey.
Capital, and the question of who owns it and therefore reaps the benefits of its productiveness, is an extremely important issue that is
Private Members' Business
complementary to the issue of full employment... .1 see these as the twin pillars of our economy: full employment of our labour resources and widespread ownership of our capital resources. Such twin pillars would go a long way in providing a firm underlying support for future economic growth that would be equitably shared.
In closing, this bill is social democracy in action. It does empower the workers. It empowers the workers though not at the expense of anyone else. It is a shared ownership of a small, medium and large corporation business industry and I would encourage that the government side and the Official Opposition support this.

speakeroldname: Mr. Pierre H. Vincent (Parliamentary Secretary to Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to start by congratulating the member on his decision to introduce a bill to promote employee shareholding in the corporation that employs them.
I agree that in some cases such participation may lead to increased productivity and as a result help strengthen our global economy. However, although enhancing cooperation between company management and its employees is praiseworthy in itself, I do not think it would necessarily be wise to adopt Bill C-327.
I would like to take this opportunity to give hon. members my views on the bill and help them decide whether the bill is acceptable in its present form.
Perhaps I may clarify the contents of Bill C-327. The purpose of this legislation is to help employees purchase shares in the company that employs them.
To that end, the bill proposes to amend the Income Tax Act to provide that employees and the employer may include in deductions from taxable income 50 per cent of their investment in an employee share purchase plan and 50 per cent of the interest paid to a financial institution for the purposes of such plans. To take advantage of these tax incentives, employees must purchase a controlling shareholding in a given corporation.
Hon. members may recall that in 1984 the previous government, in a document entitled Gain Sharing for a Stronger Economy, proposed a program that would provide a tax credit, shared between employees and employers, for the percentage of the profits allocated to employee compensation.

Private Members' Business
The purpose of this program, like most employee ownership plans, was to improve labour management relations and increase employee productivity. Further analysis of the proposal raised some doubts as to whether those objectives were realistic. The proposal, which was not well received by labour and management circles, was dropped by the government and replaced by other policies.
At this point I may add that the Income Tax Act now includes provisions that provide incentives for employee investment. More specifically, the government encourages employee investment by giving preferential tax treatment to employee share purchase options and the labour-sponsored venture capital corporation plan, which was enhanced in the last budget.
Combined with the lifetime capital gains exemption, these programs offer employees a strong incentive for investing in Canadian corporations, without introducing a bias in investment decisions.
I may add that the provisions relating to national labour-sponsored venture capital corporations restrict the percentage of the assets of such corporations that may be invested in a single business, thus reflecting the old adage that warns against putting all one's eggs in the same basket.
In the case of Bill C-327, the eggs include not only the employee's investment but also his job. I think hon. members will agree it would be inappropriate for the government to urge individuals to take such risks.
I would also like to point out that a number of provinces already have programs under which employees may purchase shares in the corporation that employs them. The federal government provides passive support for these programs by administering them under the tax collection agreements and by not counting the province's contribution as taxable income. In some cases, investments under these programs may be eligible for RRSP treatment.
Eliminating initial tax incentives like the ones proposed in Bill C-327 was one of the main thrusts of the 1988 income tax reform. One of the primary objectives of the reform was to encourage decision making in terms of economic merits as opposed to specific tax benefits. Achieving this objective involved eliminating a number
of special tax benefits that were only available to a small group of individuals.
The resulting broadening of the tax base made it possible to reduce income tax across the board. In addition to introducing greater fairness, this approach, with its broader tax base and lower tax rates, has the advantage of not influencing investment decisions and thus encouraging long-term economic growth.
Bill C-327 does the opposite, in that it would encourage the use of public funds for the benefit of a small group of individuals who wish to acquire a controlling interest in the corporation that employs them.
There was another reason for restricting the use of initial tax incentives like those proposed in Bill C-327. Experience, both in this country and abroad, has shown that a considerable share of the tax credits used in this way is applied to activities that would have taken place even if the tax credits had not been available. The activity directly due to these incentives is often insignificant. Furthermore, such tax incentives often tend to have a poor cost-benefit ratio, in terms of achieving the desired objectives.
This brings me to my other point. The adoption of Bill C-327 could have a major impact on the deficit, since this generous tax treatment might encourage many businesses to restructure their employee compensation plan so as to take advantage of this incentive. Given the importance of controlling the deficit, it would be necessary to raise the taxes of all other Canadians to support the stock acquisition plans.
In this regard, it is important for my colleagues in the House to realize that Bill C-327 proposes income redistribution, to some extent. I wonder whether such redistribution is appropriate, in view of the lack of evidence to support the alleged benefits that would flow from the bill, if adopted.
In conclusion, I would like to congratulate my colleague on taking the initiative to present this bill in the House. I believe that I speak for all Canadians when I say that increasing the productivity of our workers and improving labour-management relations are important factors in helping this great country to succeed.
June 9, 1992

Nevertheless, I really fear that Bill C-327 would not necessarily do much to achieve that. Not only would it be costly and unfair but it would not reach the objectives for which it was designed.
Thank you, Mr. Speaker, for giving me the opportunity to discuss this issue in the House and I hope that my colleagues can use this information to make a justified, fair and equitable decision when the time comes to vote on this bill.

Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to say a few words about Bill C-327 which is sponsored by my colleague and friend from Sault Ste. Marie. The bill deals with the whole question of employee ownership, which in Sault Ste. Marie and in the Algoma district we see as the only solution really to the Algoma Steel problem which faced us one year ago last February.
On that cold winter morning we were notified that Dofasco had a debt amounting to some $800 million at Algoma Steel. I must say there was great concern. We had just been through a long and costly strike in the summer and fall of 1990. We faced the prospect of the company going into receivership and the complete destruction of the economic viability, not only of the company, but of Sault Ste. Marie and the Algoma district.
As we look back at it now, in some ways it is miraculous that the working together of Dofasco and Algoma Steel personnel with United Steel Workers of America, the banking institutions and the two senior levels of government, a new Algoma has arisen out of that situation with everybody suffering, as the member has said, massive losses. The workers lost some $2.82 an hour in wages. The banks have had their equity or their investment chopped. Dofasco has lost most of its equity position.
It is hard to know whether this was inevitable or whether it was just a combination of circumstances. Clearly if there is any way for this company to survive, it is with worker ownership.
The steel industry is in a terrible situation. It went through great hardship in the United States during the 1980s when it went from about 500,000 employees to 180,000. We are going through that dramatic restructur-
Private Members' Business
ing now. The only thing is that if the governments in this country get involved in the direct financial support of the steel industry, it means that those companies will be subjected to a countervail by the United States steel industry. They are probably going to be subjected in the next couple of weeks to an anti-dumping duty just because the United States companies want to protect themselves.
The kind of massive financial assistance by all levels of government in the United States has not been provided to Canadian companies. That is not to say that the Government of Canada will not lose hundreds of millions of dollars in the Algoma case because all the losses will be written off against the taxes of the main financial banking institutions that have massive profits against which to write them off.
It does seem to me that for many industries the idea of employee ownership is very desirable. I do not presume to suggest what that exact mechanism is. Clearly government incentives are one idea.
I look back at the budget that was delivered here in the House of Commons on February 15, 1984 by Marc Lalonde. In that budget he said: "I am therefore proposing today to encourage this process with tax assistance for a new employee profit participation plan. The government will provide a tax credit of 10 per cent of the profits shared under the plan; 60 per cent of the tax credit will go to the individual workers, 40 per cent to the employer. The employee profit participation plan is designed to complement the collective bargaining process, not replace it. Experience has shown that to succeed, profit sharing cannot be a substitute for competitive wages".
We are talking about profit sharing. Mr. Lalonde proposed a whole series of tax incentives to encourage profit sharing.
The ultimate objective is to lower the tension, lower the adversarial situation which exists in many industries between employers and employees. Surely there is no way to do this better than through employers and employees owning the company.
If you cannot make the company competitive when the employees own it, you probably cannot make it competitive anyway, assuming you have good management in each case, and it is an industry which is properly capitalized and modem enough in structure.

Private Members' Business
A few weeks ago we had a conference in Sault Ste. Marie on the future of Elliot Lake. One of the principal speakers at the conference was from Tembec which is a diversified forest products company in northern Quebec. I was very impressed with not only the employee ownership in that situation but the attitude toward training and retraining of the workers. Its average training amounts to some 84 hours a year where the Canadian average is only some two hours.
It was the company that stepped in in the Kapuskasing situation where there was an employee buy-out. I was very impressed.
I think profit sharing has a long way to go in Canada because we do tend to have very adversarial relationships between employers and employees, although I do think that the hard, tough economic times that we face right now perhaps reduced that to some extent.
Employee buy-out is one mechanism. Employee participation in profit sharing is another way. Assuming that the Tory government will allow this bill to go to committee, it would be a very worth-while experience to review exactly how the incentives would be provided, whether they would be adequate or perhaps how costly they would be. I think that is the kind of thing we would learn in a committee study of this bill.
I hope the government will support the bill going to committee. I think it is an area that must be further explored.
I do not expect this government to be very generous in encouraging employee ownership or employee participation but I think it is something that is going to happen. There are many industries in this country that are going to have great difficulty surviving in the kind of modem global economy in which they are competing with low-cost producers in other countries. We must have the very maximum of co-operation between employees and employers.
There is a great value in this bill going to committee to see the details of how it could work and how well it would work. I hope that enough government members will support it to see it studied in committee. Perhaps this is the final solution and it can become the law of the
land. If that happens and it is judged by the committee and the House to be the solution, that is great. If it is not perhaps it can be amended, or perhaps the government will ultimately see that there needs to be a mechanism for employer ownership so that it is necessary to operate with the ad hoc arrangements which we had in Kapuskasing and Algoma.
The bill should get the support of the House to go to committee for a very thorough study. We are going through a change in industrial relations in this country and in the world. Employer-employee ownership is one mechanism to ensure that many of our companies, especially our resource companies, survive in this country.

speakeroldname: Mr. Murray Cardiff (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Agriculture):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Agriculture
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak today on this private member's bill, Bill C-327.
This bill proposes a 50 per cent tax deduction for investments made by employees, employers and financial institutions to finance employee takeovers of the businesses for which they work.
When assessing this bill we should examine it from various perspectives. Is the proposal good for the employees? Is it good for business? Is it good for taxpayers? I have asked myself these questions and have come to the conclusion that on the whole the proposal would not represent a clear step forward.
I shall now elaborate on why I have reached that conclusion. First, consider how this proposal would affect employees. Canadian employees work hard for their money. Out of their pay cheque they must provide for their current needs, such as food, shelter, clothing, transportation and, if they are lucky, perhaps some entertainment. The remainder of their hard-earned pay, when set aside in the form of savings, provides for the future. Employees must decide where the best place for that nest egg is.
Each individual is different in that respect. Some are prepared to take substantial risks in making investments, knowing that high rewards often accompany high risks. Others place a premium on security, sacrificing a little return in order to sleep soundly at night in the knowledge that their money will be there when they need it.
June 9, 1992

Neither the government nor I can tell these employees as a group where it is best to place their savings. That decision depends on the individual's own experience, character and perspective.
However, a 50 per cent deduction sends a strong message that the government views a particular investment, acquiring a controlling interest in the employer company, as the preferred alternative. The bill suggests that the program is intended for cases in which the financial viability of the employer is in some doubt. Such turn-around situations constitute high-risk investments, not necessarily bad investments but certainly not everyone's cup of tea.
The government should not lure employees into a risky investment with a 50 per cent tax deduction when the employees' instincts and analyses would lead them in a safer direction. Even in the absence of a tax inducement many employees may find investments in their employers to be a good home for their savings. Clearly, the government should do nothing to stand in the way of such decisions nor discourage them through punitive tax treatment.
Just as clearly the tax system should not favour a particular risky type of investment, as this bill proposes. The tax system should play a neutral role if it is to serve the employees of Canada well.
I would now like to turn to the question of whether this proposal would be good for business. The idea of employees acquiring control of their employer's business is in vogue at the moment. A recent Globe and Mail article dealt with what it described as the largest experiment in worker ownership in North American history, which is the employee acquisition of Algoma Steel Corporation Limited. Therefore, it is understandable that this bill is sponsored by the member who represents Sault Ste. Marie, the home of Algoma Steel.
When the results of this experiment are in it may turn out that employee ownership was the ideal business solution for Algoma Steel. Certainly the employees' union representative held out high hopes. Mr. Leo Gerard, the Canadian president of the United Steelworkers of America, is quoted as saying that the Algoma restructuring "shows what imagination and a willingness
Private Members' Business
to take risk can accomplish. High value-added production and a well-trained labour force need not be unrealized dreams or academic exercises". Cuts in wages and benefits were necessaiy to make the package work and this may well have been facilitated by the involvement of Algoma's employees.
Employee ownership may turn out to be the ideal business solution for Algoma Steel. It will not be so in all cases in which businesses are faced with a decision as to change in control. Existing owners may be best placed to continue operating the business given their experience and the stake they already have in making the business work. Alternatively, an outside group constituted of neither employees nor existing owners may bring fresh ideas and new business connections and therefore offer the greatest opportunities for success.
The very complex question of who is best placed to control a business so that it works well for its employees, customers and shareholders is usually answered in a simple fashion. Existing owners when faced with an offer for acquisition of control will consider whether the terms of the offer are attractive. When considering multiple offers they will decide whether the most attractive one is sufficient to convince them to relinquish the control they have. Generally, the most attractive offer will come from the source that has the best plan for the business. If existing owners have the best plan they will accept no alternative offer.
If one group is provided with tax support for their offer while others are not the decision will be tilted in a direction that is not necessarily best for the business. For example, if employees are provided with a 50 per cent tax deduction available neither to existing owners nor to outside groups, employees' offers will be attractive even if they do not make the best business sense.
We all wish to ensure that the best business decisions are reached when questions of corporate control arise. When a business thrives Canadians benefit, as employees, customers, suppliers, shareholders or simply through participation in a prosperous economy. Therefore, we should all agree to avoid using our tax system in a manner that would lead to bad business decisions in the important field of acquisition of control.

June 9, 1992
Private Members' Business
A level tax playing field is essential if we are interested in business success. Unfortunately, this bill would tilt that field.
Finally, let us consider what is best for the taxpayers of Canada. Certainly, a 50 per cent tax deduction sounds very attractive but it would be available only to a select group, the employees of target companies and others who helped finance the take-over. There are millions of Canadians who are not in the labour force, who are unemployed, self-employed or employed in the non-corporate sector. There are millions more who lack the means or the desire to invest in their employers. None of these Canadians will benefit from the proposed tax deduction. Yet these same Canadians will be called upon to foot the bill when it comes to replacing the lost revenue from this new tax deduction.
Is it fair to ask the large majority of Canadians to pay higher taxes so that a select few can benefit from a 50 per cent tax deduction on investments that may pay off handsomely? I would say no.
In summary, whether this House considers the bill from the perspective of the employee, the business or the taxpayer it will find some problems. I am confident that the House will display its usual good sense in disposing of this measure.

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George-Bulkley Valley):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to rise in the House today to participate in this debate, which is limited in time, on an excellent initiative from one of my colleagues, the member for Sault Ste. Marie.
This is an example of initiative taken by a private member. As most people who follow the proceedings of Parliament will know, one way that private members, members not in government, have an opportunity to present proposed legislation and to develop some ideas is by way of a private member's bill.
This is one particular bill where there is reason enough, I would hope, from the government side and all members of this House to vote on favourably when it does come to a vote and to send the bill to committee. Given the nature of the subject of this bill, it would present an excellent opportunity to review a very exciting and interesting subject matter.
Of course I am referring to the bill presented by my colleague, Bill C-327, and I will read the title which will explain it further. It is an act to assist employees to purchase a controlling shareholding in the corporation that employs them and to amend the Income Tax Act in consequence thereof.
Basically, it is an opportunity for us to develop in Canada a formal and structured process for employee buy-outs or to provide incentives that would make it viable as an attractive option.
This bill presented by my colleague would be the first federal legislation to specifically encourage or facilitate employee ownership. That is an important concept for us to look at.
I could go on, as some members probably have, given the difficulty that our economy is facing in Canada, and particularly in the manufacturing sector, given the pressures of the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement, which many have labelled a failure, and of course the plans by the government to get our country into a trilateral free trade agreement.
But leaving those arguments aside for now and just talking about the whole nature of the development of industry and business in Canada, and indeed throughout North America, it is clear that those modem and progressive corporations are taking a look now at being successful. And how is it that they are successful?
One of the ways they are successful, and we all know this, is to ensure they have a valuable and trained work force and given the future outcome of this particular bill, an opportunity then for those employees to share in the ownership of a particular industry. It is those innovative and new ideas that are the kinds of proposals that really do make for a successful and progressive economy in North America.
We do have some examples across North America and here in Canada on employee ownership. One of the examples cited by my colleague is a company by the name of Weirton Steel in Ohio which was to be closed in 1982 by its parent company because of low profits. The employees decided to purchase the plant which accounted for one-third or 8,400 of the total employment of that local community. Since the buy-out the plant has performed relatively well, especially in view of the depressed market for steel. We all know, of course, about the debate between Canada and the United States now on that whole particular field.
June 9, 1992

In raising that specific example, the point is that it has been demonstrated that a decision to close a plant or a facility does not necessarily mean that the operation is economically non-viable.
Business decisions are made for a vast number of reasons, not always because the plant is not profitable. We have seen a number of such transfers given our branch plant economy in Canada. We have seen the closure of branch plants in Canada and movement to the United States. That is clearly an example where employee ownership might play a role in terms of the development of industry in Canada.
Mention is made in the notes about Kapuskasing. There is a very recent success in an employee buy-out and of course in my colleague's riding, there is Algoma Steel.
It is important for us to think about that because it gives workers the opportunity to share in the development of that particular plant or industry in that sector. One comes to mind. In Saskatchewan I believe there is a brewery owned by the workers which has had incredible success, if I recall from one of the business programs that was on. It is an example of the kind of ownership route I think we ought to try to take our industry in giving the employees an opportunity to have that share in the ownership and in the direction of a firm.
I might add that in my mind it is probably the subject of another bill, legislation or debate about Crown corporations. In many ways we might need to take a look at how to get our Crown corporations to be responsive to the needs of consumers. It has been a tool that really has been accepted by all parties in Canada. It has been a tool for economic development, much abused I would say by Liberal and Conservative governments. It is an abused model that can work.
We have to ensure that when we use the services of either CN or Petro-Canada we are getting something out of it or that there is a clear return to the public treasury. I do not know if at times we have been successful at showing that. In any case it is along the same lines, I suppose, of employees having some say in the development of those particular operations.
This bill will go some distance toward dealing with the issue. It deserves the support of the government, at the
Private Members' Business
very least, to vote and pass the bill. Then we could get it to committee where there could be a fascinating look at the whole concept of employee ownership. This bill could spur that discussion. In committee there could be very reasonable discussion. There could be witnesses from a number of these plants and facilities where it has worked.
Let us hear from the opponents of the idea who do not think it will work. Let us hear from the chambers of commerce and the trade union movement as to their views. It would be a very interesting study. That is reason enough for the government to tiy to move this legislation through and into committee.
Let me just mention a few other points in the bill just for detail so that the people who read this debate later will have some background. Part of the bill's plan is for half of the employees' or corporation's contributions plan to be deducted. Borrowing by a plan's trustees to purchase shares would be made easier by allowing lending institutions a tax deduction of half the interest earned.
The bill requires-and I think this is important-that the plan be agreed to by all parties involved: the management and the shareholders. Of course the Minister of National Revenue must agree in terms of the implications on the Income Tax Act in this case. Most important, we are seeing some support of initiatives in this particular case.
This particular initiative brought forward by my colleague has been endorsed by many groups including the Sault Ste. Marie Chamber of Commerce and various labour groups. Obviously there is the work here. I hope members of the public after hearing, will write their letters of support to the member for Sault Ste. Marie urging government members and other members of the House to support this legislation.
It will be a real opportunity for employee ownership whose time has come and for Canadian employees to be given the opportunity to save their jobs and work together to keep Canada strong.
I would encourage the government to offer its support to this bill, to send it to committee where all these issues could be surveyed and to say yes to a good idea from the member for Sault Ste. Marie.

June 9, 1992
Adjournment Debate

speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as has been noted, the subject of debate before us today is private member's Bill C-327, recommending that this government encourage the financial participation of workers in the firms in which they are employed.
I begin by thanking the hon. member for raising the issue of improving the relationship between management and labour. This government shares the hon. member's concerns that to remain competitive we need increased co-operation between labour and management. This will be critical in the long-term growth of the Canadian economy.
As members may be aware, Bill C-327 recommends that the Income Tkx Act be amended to provide a 50 per cent deduction from taxable income for employee and employer investments in employee share purchase plans and on interest income earned on loans by financial institutions to such plans. It is important to note that the purchase of shares is not enough. Under this proposal employees must in fact acquire control of the target firm.
Mr. Speaker, as you will no doubt recall, a similar proposal was put forth by the previous government in 1984. That program would have provided a tax credit shared between employees and employers for employee remuneration paid in the form of a percentage of profits. Like the current proposal, the objective of that plan was to enhance worker productivity through improved relationship between labour and management. You may also recall that both labour and management groups expressed dissatisfaction with that proposal. After careful study by this government the plan was rejected.
This should not come as a surprise to anyone who is aware of the objectives that this government espoused in tax reform. As members are aware, one of the primary objectives of tax reform was to encourage decisions based on economic merit rather than special tax preferences. This was accomplished by the elimination of numerous preferences, preferences that in many cases were available to only a small group of people. At the same time many deductions were either eliminated or replaced by credits.
The combined effect of this base broadening permitted the reduction of tax rates. As a result many Canadians,
particularly low income recipients and seniors, enjoyed a reduction in their tax liabilities.
Most important of all was the fact that tax reform was a major step in reducing the distortions in economic decision making through the income tax system. This broad based, low rate approach to income taxation left savings decisions undistorted thus encouraging the longterm growth of the economy.

Mr. Speaker, I want to speak briefly today on Canada's printing industry. As we know it is Canada's fourth largest industrial employer with 78,000 employees working today in Canada.
This industry is comprised of 4,300 different establishments, which means that the average work force in each one of these establishments is under 20 employees. This industry is really a Canadian industry. It is 96 per cent Canadian owned. A lot of them are family owned and have been in business for many years.
What has happened recently is a disaster. Like many of our other industries the printing industry has been hit very hard by the recession, but even worse by free trade.
Last year my province of Ontario lost 5,500 printing jobs. There is 14 per cent unemployment among printers themselves. In the rest of the country we lost 4,700 jobs in just one year in this industry which is quintessential^ Canadian. In just one year, last year, we lost 10,200 jobs. The people who work in this industry are proud and fine people.
June 9, 1992

What has this done to our trading relationship with the United States? We do about $750 million annual trade both ways with the United States, but our deficit in trade with the United States in 1988 was $106 million. Last year it was $332 million. This was an increase in our trading deficit of 213 per cent. This is not good for Canada. The loss of jobs is not good for Canada. There is the loss of foreign exchange.
Now why has this happened? The printing industry has analysed its plight. It cites the high Canadian dollar. It says that under free trade because the industry is small, under 20 employees per firm, the industry needs it more than the five year phase-out of tariffs under the free trade deal. The printing industry asked for the 10 years and did not get it. So consequently, it has been left at a competitive disadvantage. The higher taxes in Canada are cited, including lower capital cost allowances to invest in new machinery and equipment.
One of the interesting facts is the actual working of the free trade agreement itself under the country of origin markings. Since free trade, because of this factor alone $160,000 in sales and 1,700 jobs have been lost.
The U.S. laws are more stringent. They are enforced with greater zeal and there is a buy American program. Our printers simply want a level playing field. They are prepared to compete but they are not getting it from our laws or from our enforcement of the free trade.
We have to support our industry. It has come up with its own buy Canadian program, a printed in Canada logo, proudly Canadian. This is the industry's answer to the buy American program. Let us get behind our printers and give them the support that only government can and which they so richly deserve.

speakeroldname: Mr. Marcel R. Tremblay (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport) and Minister of State (Youth) and Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will gladly answer the hon. member for Willowdale by telling him that Revenue Canada Customs and Excise is in charge of enforcing the marking of imported goods
Adjournment Debate
order requiring that the country of origin be marked on some imports when they come into Canada.
As regards the marking of printed material, requirements are as stringent in Canada as in the United States. Generally, there should be a country of origin marking on all stationery items, lithographic prints and printed matter.
In response to the concerns of the Canadian Printing Industries Association, our officials have undertaken a review of how we enforce the marking of imported goods order.
We are working in particular on administrative directives regarding the size and location of the country of origin markings as well as on amendments to current exemptions for printed matter.
We expect these guidelines to strike a balance between the Canadian requirements and the American ones. We met with the Canadian Printing Industries Association in April to give a progress report on this.
Before any change is implemented, the importing community and the printing associations will of course have to be advised of the changes we plan in terms of the enforcement of the marking requirements.
As far as the enforcement of the program by Customs is concerned, I can assure you that our officials enforce the order most cleverly.
Moreover, complaints from the Canadian Printing Industries Association have been investigated and, when required, corrective measures have been taken.

Mr. Speaker, last Friday, June 5,1 asked the Minister of Employment and Immigration a question regarding the dismal unemployment statistics released that day.
I received a very unsatisfactory answer. It was unsatisfactory not only to myself, but also to many Canadians across this country and especially people who are unemployed.

June 9, 1992
Adjournment Debate
The figures announced that day gave the unemployment rate at 11.2 per cent for the month of May. Now the prospect of finding a job in my province of Prince Edward Island is even worse because the unemployment figures there are 19.1 per cent. That is the highest monthly unemployment rate ever reported by Statistics Canada in my province. There is a personal face behind all these statistics.
People need jobs. They need jobs for their self-respect and for their dignity. Certainly these people are looking to the federal government to change some of its economic policies because these policies simply have not worked. Although inflation is important, job creation must also be a part of the federal government's economic strategy.
Perhaps more than anyone else in this country, Canadian youth is paying the price of this government's economic policies. The unemployment rate among youths in this country is 17.8 per cent. There are 114,000 fewer young people employed this year than in May of last year. Right now many students are looking for work and they have little or no hope of finding summer jobs.
In Atlantic Canada the youth unemployment rate is 30.3 per cent. That figure is unacceptable. I am astounded that this government does not recognize the need to act on this very serious situation.
Many of these students were planning to work this summer to pay for their expenses at college or at university next year. This government has simply let them down because it has not taken any action to provide the much needed jobs.
At the same time this government is hurting students in other ways. It has not recognized that the cost allowance for students under the student loan program has not been increased since 1984 even though tuition fees and other expenses continue to go up every year.
I want to end by saying there is no question that we need a change of leadership. We need new economic policies. We need policies that will create jobs.
For the sake of all Canadians, let us hope that this change comes sooner rather than later.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on behalf of the Minister of Employment and Immigration, I am pleased to provide the hon. member for Malpeque with some more information on the questions she herself raised here in this House on June 5.
The government cares about the difficult situation in which Atlantic Canadians find themselves. That is why the government commits $425 million on average every year for regional development projects in the Atlantic provinces.
Furthermore, the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency continues to draw up and implement programs that promote economic development in the Atlantic region. By the end of March 1992, a net amount of $745 million had been committed in grants and contributions under ACOA's action program.
The government developed strategies to rebuild and diversify the fishing industry in the Atlantic region. Under the Atlantic Fisheries Adjustment Program, the Government of Canada will commit a total of $584 million to the fishing sector; $120 million will be allocated to a program to help fish-processing plant workers adjust; $146 million will be spent to help diversify the region's economy; $150 million will be used to reconstitute the fish stocks; $130 million will be allocated under the Labour Force Development Strategy to community development programs and projects intended to help older and aging workers adjust.
Finally, under the Labour Force Development Strategy, unemployment insurance funds for labour market programs have increased 280 per cent, from $500 million in 1990 to $1.95 billion in 1992. These funds will be used to help the unemployed acquire new skills and to encourage the private sector to provide more training for its workers.
